validationRules.svgList: Required when selectSvg is 'preBuild', icon name from library
validationRules.customSVG: Required when selectSvg is 'custom', must have valid SVG file URL
validationRules.strokeColor: Valid CSS color (hex, rgba, rgb, color name)
validationRules.fillColor: Valid CSS color, requires fillToggle: true
validationRules.duration: Number string in frames (30-200 typical range, 60 = 1 second at 60fps)

warnings: Custom SVGs must be true vector SVG files, not rasterized images saved as SVG
Complex SVGs with many paths may perform poorly with oneByOne drawing
Loop animation (hoverDraw: 'loop') continuously consumes CPU - use sparingly
Duration too short (<30 frames) may appear glitchy or too fast to perceive
Duration too long (>200 frames) may frustrate users waiting for completion
fillToggle without fillColor defined may result in default black fill
Large SVG files (>100KB) should be optimized with SVGO or similar tools
SVGs with embedded images or text may not animate correctly - use pure paths
Hover trigger (hoverDraw: 'onHover') requires clear hover area - ensure sufficient size
Scroll trigger accuracy depends on viewport visibility threshold
commonMistakes: Uploading rasterized PNG/JPG saved as SVG instead of true vector SVG
Not optimizing SVG files - including unnecessary metadata, comments, or hidden layers
Setting fillToggle: true without defining fillColor (defaults to black)
Using onHover trigger with tiny icons (<60px) - hard to hover accurately
Setting duration too short (e.g., 10 frames) - animation completes instantly
Using loop trigger on multiple elements - causes performance issues
Not providing responsive maxWidth (md/sm/xs) - huge SVGs on mobile
Using selectSvg: 'custom' without uploading customSVG file
Expecting fill animation when fillToggle is false - only stroke animates
Using complex gradients or filters in custom SVG - may break animation
bestPractices: Optimize custom SVGs with SVGO or similar tools before uploading (<50KB ideal)
Use delayed or sync drawType for most use cases - oneByOne for special reveals
Set duration between 60-120 frames (1-2 seconds) for smooth, pleasant animation
Use onScroll trigger for hero sections and key visual elements
Use onHover for interactive icons and cards
Reserve loop trigger for subtle ambient animations only
Provide responsive sizing (md/sm/xs) for optimal mobile display
Match strokeColor to brand colors for visual consistency
Use fillToggle sparingly - stroke-only animations often more elegant
Center-align large decorative SVGs for balance
Left-align small feature icons for list alignment
Test SVG animation on different scroll speeds - ensure it's always visible
Use contrasting stroke colors against backgrounds for visibility
Keep SVG complexity reasonable - fewer paths = better performance
Consider using pre-built icons for common symbols to save upload time
accessibilityNotes: Add alt text via block settings for SVG icons (screen readers)
Use role='img' and aria-label for decorative SVGs
Ensure sufficient color contrast for stroke/fill colors (WCAG AA)
Don't rely solely on color - SVG should be recognizable in grayscale
Consider users with motion sensitivity - provide option to disable animations
Ensure SVG content doesn't convey critical information lost when not animated
Test with screen readers to ensure SVG meaning is communicated
Use semantic HTML around SVGs for context (e.g., <figure> with <figcaption>)
Avoid flashing animations that may trigger photosensitive epilepsy
Ensure hover-triggered animations don't hide important content
Provide keyboard navigation for interactive SVG elements
Consider prefers-reduced-motion CSS to disable animations for sensitive users
performanceConsiderations: Optimize SVGs with SVGO - remove unnecessary attributes, comments, metadata
Keep SVG file size <50KB for fast loading (ideally <20KB)
Limit number of paths in complex SVGs - more paths = more CPU for animation
Use CSS animations over JavaScript where possible (GPU-accelerated)
Avoid loop animations on multiple elements simultaneously - CPU intensive
Test on low-end devices - complex SVG animations may drop frames
Use will-change: transform on animated SVG elements for rendering optimization
Consider lazy loading SVGs below the fold to improve initial page load
Inline small (<5KB) SVGs directly in HTML to save HTTP requests
Monitor animation frame rate - aim for consistent 60fps

delayed.description: Staggered drawing - paths animate with slight delay between each
delayed.visualAppearance: Paths start drawing one after another with overlap, creating flowing wave effect
delayed.bestFor: Logos, brand graphics, smooth multi-path reveals, professional feel

sync.description: Synchronous drawing - all paths animate simultaneously
sync.visualAppearance: All strokes appear at the same time, unified reveal
sync.bestFor: Simple icons, single-path graphics, fast reveals, badges

oneByOne.description: Sequential drawing - paths animate completely one at a time
oneByOne.visualAppearance: First path completes fully, then second starts, creating step-by-step reveal
oneByOne.bestFor: Illustrations, storytelling, complex graphics, dramatic reveals
oneByOne.performance: Moderate - higher CPU for complex SVGs

onScroll.description: Animate when element scrolls into viewport
onScroll.when: Element becomes visible in browser window
onScroll.bestFor: Hero sections, feature graphics, scroll-triggered reveals, storytelling
onScroll.notes: Animation plays once when scrolled into view (IntersectionObserver)

onHover.when: User hovers mouse cursor over SVG
onHover.bestFor: Interactive icons, cards, buttons, engagement elements, tooltips
onHover.notes: Animation replays each time user hovers

loop.bestFor: Ambient animations, loading indicators, subtle backgrounds, badges
loop.notes: CPU-intensive - use sparingly, consider performance impact

toolsRecommended: SVGO (command line or GUI) - remove unnecessary data
Adobe Illustrator 'Export As' SVG - with 'Presentation Attributes' checked
Figma SVG export - with 'Outline stroke' option
whatToRemove: Excessive decimal precision (2 decimal places sufficient)
Text elements (convert to paths for animation)
whatToKeep: Stroke and fill attributes (for animation control)
Basic shapes (circle, rect, polygon) as paths

useCaseTips: Brand Logos: Use delayed drawType, 120 frames, onScroll trigger, center alignment
Feature Icons: Use sync drawType, 60-90 frames, onScroll trigger, left alignment for lists
Interactive Cards: Use oneByOne drawType, 60 frames, onHover trigger for engagement
Ambient Animations: Use sync drawType, 100 frames, loop trigger for subtle motion
Hero Graphics: Use delayed drawType, 150-180 frames, onScroll trigger for dramatic impact

integrationExamples.name: Convert Text to Paths in Illustrator
integrationExamples.description: Ensure text in SVG animates correctly
integrationExamples.code:
1. Select all text elements in Illustrator
2. Type > Create Outlines (Cmd/Ctrl + Shift + O)
3. File > Export > Export As > SVG
4. Options: Presentation Attributes (checked)

integrationExamples.name: Optimize SVG with SVGO Command Line
integrationExamples.description: Reduce file size and clean up SVG
integrationExamples.code:
# Install SVGO
npm install -g svgo

# Optimize single file
svgo input.svg -o output.svg

# Optimize with custom config (preserve viewBox)
svgo input.svg --multipass --config '{"plugins":[{"removeViewBox":false}]}'
